Award.AwardTitle: Exploration of a Statistically Accurate and Energy Efficient Accelerated Testing Methodology

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this fundamental research is to explore a new accelerated testing (AT) methodology that improves the reliability estimation accuracy of an AT experiment while minimizing its total energy consumption. The basic idea of AT is to expose test units of a product to harsher-than-normal operating conditions to expedite failures. However, AT often consumes significant amounts of energy. To avoid the waste of energy in a wide spectrum of product development processes, this research will increase our knowledge by incorporating control theory into such complex experimental designs that require new tools to jointly handle statistical estimation accuracy, controller design, and energy assessment via computer simulation. The methodology will determine the interrelationship between various stress loadings and total energy use, establish a generic framework to facilitate the optimum experimental design and energy reduction process, and provide advanced control strategies capable of following various stress loadings. To validate the methodology, the long-term reliability of solder joints will be studied, which is quite challenging in the microelectronics industry and is essential for millions of applications.

If successful, this research will change the current reliability testing practices in developing highly reliable products (or materials) that are continually faced with increasing needs for time- and energy-saving technologies. Considering millions of products being developed in the U.S. and the world, energy reduction in reliability testing for each stage of a development process will eventually lead to substantial energy savings. This research complements the world-wide sustainability efforts in actively seeking new energy resources. The research findings will also enhance education and knowledge dissemination in reliability engineering, equipment and control, statistics, and energy-saving technologies. Moreover, the results will be broadly disseminated through publications, workshops, and industry collaborations. Furthermore, minority and female students will be recruited in this project and K-12 teachers and students will be exposed to cutting edge research experiences.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to explore a new experimental design methodology that improves the product reliability estimation precision and reduces the total energy consumption of accelerated tests (AT).

We have studied in depth a unique experimental design methodology that requires a double-loop design architecture. The resulting statistically precise and energy efficient AT plan depends not only on the reliability of the product to be evaluated but also on the physical characteristics of the test equipment and its controller. A collection of mathematical formulations, computational algorithms and simulation tools has been developed to handle such complex experimental design problems. In particular, two approaches to solving the related large-scale optimization problems have been successfully developed and implemented: (1) optimizing statistical estimation precision followed by energy minimization, and (2) optimizing statistical estimation precision and energy consumption simultaneous, in an experimental design process. A software package has been developed to automate these approaches. Our numerical examples demonstrate that the resulting AT plans have significant potential for reducing the total energy consumption (e.g., 63%) of AT without sacrificing the estimation precision.

This is the first methodological investigation on experimental design of statistically precise and energy efficient AT. It is expected that successful implementations of the new experimental design methodology will promote radical changes in current reliability testing practices as an indispensable part of various product development processes. Many industries, such as the automotive industry and microelectronics industry, will benefit from the reduction in total energy consumption, uncertainty in product reliability, and total costs of developing a reliable product. The research also indicates a new application of control theory in the optimum design of experiments.

The research activities have resulted in 3 journal publications:

1. Liao, H.T. and Zhang, D., "Statistically Precise and Energy Efficient Accelerated Life Testing", SAE Int. J. Mater. Manuf. V. 4(1), 2011, p. 992-998.

2. Zhang, D and Liao, HT, "Design of Statistically and Energy Efficient Accelerated Life Testing Experiments", IIE Transactions, V. 46(10), 2014, p. 1031-1049.

3. Zhang, Y and Liao, HT, "Analysis of Destructive Degradation Tests for a Product with Random Degradation Initiation Time", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, V. 63(3), 2014.


Last Modified: 08/19/2014
Modified by: Haitao Liao
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project is to explore a new experimental design methodology that improves the product reliability estimation precision and reduces the total energy consumption of accelerated tests (AT). We have studied in depth a unique experimental design methodology that requires a double-loop design architecture. The resulting statistically precise and energy efficient AT plan depends not only on the reliability of the product to be evaluated but also on the physical characteristics of the test equipment and its controller. A collection of mathematical formulations, computational algorithms and simulation tools has been developed to handle such complex experimental design problems. In particular, two approaches to solving the related large-scale optimization problems have been successfully developed and implemented: (1) optimizing statistical estimation precision followed by energy minimization, and (2) optimizing statistical estimation precision and energy consumption simultaneous, in an experimental design process. A software package has been developed to automate these approaches. Our numerical examples demonstrate that the resulting AT plans have significant potential for reducing the total energy consumption (e.g., 63%) of AT without sacrificing the estimation precision. This is the first methodological investigation on experimental design of statistically precise and energy efficient AT. It is expected that successful implementations of the new experimental design methodology will promote radical changes in current reliability testing practices as an indispensable part of various product development processes. Many industries, such as the automotive industry and microelectronics industry, will benefit from the reduction in total energy consumption, uncertainty in product reliability, and total costs of developing a reliable product. The research also indicates a new application of control theory in the optimum design of experiments. The research activities have resulted in 3 journal publications: 1. Liao, H.T. and Zhang, D., "Statistically Precise and Energy Efficient Accelerated Life Testing", SAE Int. J. Mater. Manuf. V. 4(1), 2011, p. 992-998. 2. Zhang, Y and Liao, HT, "Analysis of Destructive Degradation Tests for a Product with Random Degradation Initiation Time", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, V. 63(3), 2014.
